annotation.TEXT: Transitioning ahead a bit (mainly after buying an unlocker sub-chip and switching up a few things in the chip folder), it's finally time to deal with the bank area. I've alluded to it a few times before, but there's a good reason as to why I've saved this one for last...

IceMan.EXE's Navi chip is pretty decent, and it definitely serves as a better area-of-effect attack than Bright Man's chip. Essentially, it sends out several ice shards in both directions, which then turn into pillars when they hit the ground. As for his ability chip, the Ice Slasher serves as a good projectile weapon...though strangely, it doesn't freeze things (a bit odd, considering how many old ideas Capcom seemed to recycle for this game).

QuickMan.EXE is an interesting one, to say the least. He has the ability to counter your attacks, much like BrightMan.EXE. Unlike him however, Quick Man will leave himself open for far longer when he tries to counter-attack you. It makes him far easier by comparison. Honestly, he's actually pretty fun to fight once you understand his movements (even though you can take him down quite swiftly - pun completely intended).

Yup...MM7 and X5 weren't the only games beyond MM2 to bring back this loathsome gimmick. I could rant all day about why these lasers are (and always will be) a bad idea, but honestly...I'm more baffled by their sound choice than anything. Granted, most of the sound effects in this game aren't particularly good, but these lasers sound like something straight out of a Saturday morning cartoon.
* Lasers kill you instantly, regardless of health upgrades.

On a completely different matter...am I the only one slightly disappointed by some of the enemy designs in this game? Mainly, the ones clearly derived from the classic series enemies (Shield Attackers, Sniper Joes, etc). Part of the appeal of the Battle Network series - at least, for me anyways - is the redesigning of characters (though at the same time, they manage to keep some familiar elements as well). Here, however...some of these enemy designs are basically lifted from the classic series with no changes what-so-ever. It feels like a wasted opportunity to give the enemies some neat visual revamps that tie in with BN's setting.

Time for the usual course of action: Re-fight the previous Navi to obtain their chip, then move on to the actual stage. Admittedly I wanted to do two stages this time around, but that plan sort of went out the window due to the plot progression that happened afterwards.
Aside from using the Dash Attack, I honestly have no idea how you're supposed to get to that blue mystery data without taking a hit from the spikes here.

And here's where the real laser drop begins. As a side-note, I realized I missed a locked mystery data during this segment (I went back off-screen to get it). While on the subject of locked datas, though...for anyone else who has played this game and made it up to this point: Do you recall there being two locked datas in this segment? Specifically, one that should be above a green mystery data seen at 4:57 in this video. I swear, on previous runs in this game, I distinctly remember there being a locked data in that spot. Yet now...it's not here. Is there something more to this? Or am I just going crazy?
^ Reminder: Lan beats Chaud in pretty much every single BN game. Chaud still passes it off as a fluke.
